Description: The Israeli hub of the WEF C4IR network, advancing smart regulation for emerging technologies such as AI and blockchain, through collaboration with government regulators and the tech industry in Israel.
Background: In July 2019, Israel joined the World Economic Forum’s Centre for the Fourth Industrial Revolution. The Israeli hub operates under the Israel Innovation Authority.
Objective(s): To co-design, test and refine governance protocols and policy frameworks to maximize the benefits and minimize the risks of advanced science and technology.To develop, implement and scale-up agile and human-centred pilot projects that can be adopted by policy-makers, legislators and regulators worldwide.To collaborate with national regulators to advance smart regulations for emerging technologies.
Responsible organisation(s): Israel Innovation Authority (IIA;)|Prime Minister's office (PMO;)|Ministry of Economy (;)
Theme(s): Artificial intelligence (AI)|Ethics of emerging technologies|Horizontal policy coordination|Policy experiments
Target group type(s): Firms by size|Governmental entities|Social groups especially emphasised
Target group(s): Civil society|Firms of any size|National government
Policy instrument description(s):
The Israel Innovation Authority will represent Israel at C4IR.

Joining a network of countries including the US, China, Japan, and India, Israel will leverage its participation in the program to promote regulatory changes and to be exposed to regulatory innovation and technological governance worldwide. Israel’s participation will promote the smooth integration of innovative technologies into the Israeli economy and enable the Israeli hi-tech industry to secure its global leadership in new areas of activity.

The WEF established C4IR to create an international network of regulatory agencies, with an eye toward bridging regulation and technological progress, addressing shared challenges, and formulating solutions to be piloted in different countries.
Policy instrument mini-field(s): Exchanges take place via: Meetings and events|Focus: Business innovation-oriented|Objective(s): Promote economic growth (e.g. productivity, competitiveness), Promote business partnerships (e.g. consortia-building)|Ownership of IP stemming from science-industry research: Not applicable|Share of the platform's funding coming from the private sector (as a % of total funding): 0%

English name: AI STRATEGY GOVERNMENTAL TEAM - IN PROCESS
Description: A cross-governmental team was set up to devise recommendations for a policy plan to promote AI R&I activities in Israel
Objective(s): To design a cross-agency and cross-sector policy plan to promote AI in Israel.
Responsible organisation(s): Prime Minister's office (PMO;)|Ministry of Defense (;)|Israel Innovation Authority (IIA;)|National Cyber Directorate (;)|Council for Higher Education (CHE;)
Theme area(s): Emerging trends in STI policy|Science-industry knowledge transfer and sharing
Theme(s): Artificial intelligence (AI)|Ethics of emerging technologies|Transfer and sharing strategies
Policy instrument type: Formal consultation of stakeholders or experts
Policy instrument mini-field(s): Method: Participatory workshops and seminars, Expert groups|Number of participants: 25 to 100|Stakeholders contribute to: Policy design

Description: The Council for Higher Education has established a program to support data science research within Israeli universities, including new research centers, an inter-university coordination mechanism, a dedicated fund within the Israel Science Foundation, and scholarship programs.
Objective(s): To promote cutting edge collaborative research in the field of data science.
Target group type(s): Research and education organisations|Researchers, students and teachers
Target group(s): Established researchers|Higher education institutes|PhD students|Postdocs and other early-career researchers|Undergraduate and master students
Policy instrument mini-field(s): Criteria for funding: Research publications and outputs (excellence), Research impact, Research-active staff, Research infrastructure|Funding amount allocated for an average time-period of: 4-6 years|Funding includes a teaching component: No|Funding is attached to: Strategic programme or other policy initiative|Penalties and rewards associated to performance: Bonuses and incentives|Performance-based element to the allocation: Yes

English name: AI R&D FRAMEWORK AND ACTIVITIES OF THE ISRAELI INNOVATION AUTHORITY
Original name(s): מסגרת פעילות של רשות החדשנות בתחומי בינה מלאכותית
Description:
The Planned AI R&D Framework & Activities in progress include the following activities:
A. Joint National Infrastructure for Computing and Storage.
B. Creating and allow access to data sets in multiple domains: Food, Agriculture, Autonomous vehicle, etc.
C. Building research laboratories, institutes and incubators to support research in a specific domain: Industrial robots, plants inspection, etc.
D. Supporting common national infrastructure and tools for training and development.
E. Encouraging entrepreneurship: Young Entrepreneurs, creating consortia to support Future Emerging Challenges.
Background:
- Around 1,200 active AI companies.
- 90% of the companies employs less than 50 engineers.
- Only 32 companies based on IP transferred from the academia, AI requires access to high quality big data,
- Governed and national data bases for research is not readily available.
- Data storage and computing facilities are based on foreign infrastructure.
- No Hebrew NLP and AI based on commercial tools.
- High Demand for AI talents at all levels.
- Shortage in AI graduates from the academia.
- Private sector mitigating the gap with training offering outside the academia.
Objective(s): To create a knowledge facility and infrastructure to support the Israeli industry.
Theme(s): Artificial intelligence (AI)|National STI plan or strategy
Target group type(s): Economic actors (individuals)|Firms by age|Firms by size|Intermediaries|Social groups especially emphasised
Target group(s): Disadvantaged and excluded groups|Entrepreneurs|Firms of any age|Firms of any size|Incubators, accelerators, science parks or technoparks
Policy instrument type: Creation or reform of governance structure or public body
